headline: Money pours into Arizona secretary of state race after 2020 ballot review
author: Mary Jo Pitzl
sentences:
Lawmaker fined $62K for not disclosing donors, pays $1K Arizona could take oversight of toxic coal waste disposal Election deniers file lawsuit to ban machines Biggs said to push early for alternate electors
However, nearly half of his PC total came from the Leadership for Educational Equity, a Washington D.C.-based organization that works to end inequities in education.

A report from the Brennan Center for Justice examined early finance reports from three battleground states — Michigan, Georgia and Minnesota — and found fundraising was already 2 1/2 times greater than the previous two election cycles in which voters chose their state's top elections administrator.

Candidates for Arizona secretary of state raised $2.2 million in 2021, reflecting the keen interest in election issues following the narrow margin of victory in the U.S. presidential contest and the ensuing ballot review of Maricopa County's results.

Campaign messages, which focus heavily on election processes, from how ballots are created to how they are counted, can sway voters as the campaigns aim toward the Aug. 2 primary and the general election Nov. 8.

Democratic contenders Adrian Fontes and state Rep. Reginald Bolding each raised more than the other two Republican candidates: Sen. Michelle Ugenti-Rita, R-Scottsdale, and Rep. Shawnna Bolick, R-Phoenix.
The cumulative fundraising is more than triple the amount candidates raised at this point in the campaign four years ago, according to reports filed with the Secretary of State's Office.
Leading all candidates was advertising executive Edward "Beau" Lane, who posted just over a $716,000 haul since quietly entering the race for the Republican nomination in late June.

Expect record amounts in campaign fundraising
The competitive race for the state's top election official is in line with other swing states that were crucial to the 2020 election.
Finchem reported $1,000 from the Arizona Petroleum Marketers Association, and Ugenti Rita a combined $500 from Fennemore Craig PAC and the mining firm Freeport McMoran.
There is a handicap for four of the candidates: as sitting lawmakers, Bolding, Bolick, Finchem and Ugenti-Rita cannot fundraise while the Legislature is in session.
Many of the contributions came from small-dollar donors and many from out of state — perhaps due to an endorsement from former President Donald Trump in September.
In addition to the $2.2 million raised through 2021, four of the six candidates are entering the election year with six-figure bank accounts holding cash on hand.
They include health care, social service and trial lawyer PACs, many of which lobby at the state Capitol, where Bolding serves as House minority leader.
Finchem spent $19,000 in September for a mass mailing, for a total thus far of $95,266 to the Florida-based campaign firm Go Right Strategies.

PACs, self-financing part of totals
The reports show that both Lane and Fontes dug into their own pockets to help finance their campaigns.

Fundraising hiatus for lawmakers
Spending thus far has focused on consultants, fund-raising costs and other administrative expenses.
He raised about $663,000 since launching his campaign last spring on a wave of false claims that the 2020 election was stolen.
The findings, the report states, "suggests we will see record amounts of money in election administrator contests in 2022."
Bolick received $1,450 from four PACs: Raytheon, the law firm of Fennemore Craig, Salt River Project and the Lumen AZ PAC.
Fontes, the former Maricopa County Recorder who helped run the 2020 presidential election, raised about 385,000 in 2021.
Ian Vandewalker, the senior counsel for the center's Democracy Project, projected the numbers will continue to climb.
His report showed more contributions coming in at the maximum $5,300 limit allowed by law than any other campaign.
The number of political action committees giving to the candidates was minimal across the six-candidate field.
Ugenti-Rita collected about $94,000 and Bolick just shy of $157,000, reports filed over the weekend show.
Independent expenditure committees can offset that, although none have emerged at this early date.
Bolding led the way, with contributions from 20 political action committees, totaling $21,580.

Lane drew four-figure contributions from a number of business owners and CEOs.
